title: Letter: Apple wearables promise one reader a good laugh
text:
Having read “Health challenge: Medical practice lags behind scientific discovery and wearables technology” (Report, January 5) the unanswered question is why Apple doesn't go the whole hog and sell toy stethoscopes and headdresses with embroidered little red crosses.

I am sure Leonardo da Vinci felt that his drawings of flying machines were “lagging behind their potential”. There is a reason why 99.9 per cent of doctors are “not on board”- 100 per cent of wearables produce reams of useless information. A pretty good measure of how one sleeps is how one feels the next day; no amount of pulse measurements or buckets of confetti for “steps” will detect hypertension.

It is not very encouraging that Apple is “invigorated by stories of customers whose lives have been improved”. Another word for “stories” is “anecdote” which has always been the enemy of science.

I presume that this article was published with good reason on the page facing details of the Elizabeth Holmes trial: both wearables and Theranos are on the same Silicon Valley naive dream-spectrum.

But doctors have had a tough couple of years. If you have an Apple Watch, please do share your data with us, we need a good laugh.

John Meenan
London SW6, UK
